xwikidoc.title: Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome
Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.description: This opinion piece criticises Medicare for all, though it's not clear which proposal he's talking about.

property.title: Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: no matter how many grants for research a medical center gets, it is really the surgeries and procedures that help pay for the academic side. Patients may not consider this factor until the heart surgeon or plastic surgeon they choose to perform their operation decides to leave for another country or a medical center’s latest new biochemical or promising genetic modulation can’t get sufficient funding for the research to be completed.

property.rebuttal:
Here's the scenario he seems to be painting: someone chooses a surgeon and schedules a surgery, and then Medicare For All passes, and then the surgeon leaves the country because of it before the surgery. Is that really a potential problem? Wouldn't it take many months, or years for Medicare For All to pass and take effect? Wouldn't it take more months or years for it to cause doctors to flee the country?
In any case, he makes no case for why doctors might flee the country. The implication from previous paragraph is that doctors would be paid (40%) less. But that's not a convincing argument that doctors will flee to other countries. They may still make more, even far more, in the US than in other countries. Jumping To Conclusion.
As for research funding, why should surgeries pay for that? Why can't the US fund research the way other countries do?

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: "Medicare for all" is also popular among more than half of doctors by some surveys. But I’m sure these doctors aren’t considering the difficulty with approvals, and the excess waiting times for specialists and procedures.

property.rebuttal: How are you sure you know what half of all doctors in the US are thinking?

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: These painful processes are all too common and getting worse in our single payer neighbor to the north.

property.rebuttal: There are thousands of facets to health care systems, and many different single-payer systems. Picking three facets of one country's system is cherry-picking.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: Rationing care and several weeks wait to obtain specialized care is sure to dampen innovation at a time of tremendous advances in robotics, genetic and immunotherapies.

property.rebuttal: Rationing and waiting are issues affecting patients. They have nothing to do with innovation in the medical industry.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: If "Medicare for all" ever takes over here, personalized treatments will be difficult to obtain via a health-care system that will actually be closer to Medicaid than to Medicare in terms of quality. Keep in mind that 30 percent of today’s doctors already don’t take on new Medicaid patients because of lower reimbursements and rigid regulations.

property.rebuttal: The second sentence doesn't even come close to supporting the claim in the first. And the implication is that Medicaid care is bad. Is it really? An even if it is, might the lower costs be worth it?

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: It’s also no wonder that less than half of those surveyed favor "Medicare for all" once they discover the price tag — more than $30 trillion to transition to this new system over 10 years.

property.rebuttal: This is the classic Lie of Omission. He points out that MFA would cost $30T, but studies show it would *save* far more than that. If I tell you a newly leased car will cost $10,000 per year, you may think that's a lot. But if your current car lease is costing $15,000 per year, you're actually saving. By not mentioning the current cost, he is misleading people into thinking it costs an *additional* $30T.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: This exorbitant price tag is going to have to be accompanied by a large tax hike.

property.rebuttal: Right, a tax hike of $6,000 per person per year. Which sounds like a lot, until you realize that Americans are paying $12,000 per year currently. Not through taxes, but through insurance payments, mostly paid by employers and employees. The money paid by employers is not "free". If companies no longer have to pay the $6,000 per employee, they will (at least in theory) raise salaries by roughly that same amount.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: Millions of jobs would be lost due to the collapse of the private health sector.

property.rebuttal: Assuming he means the "health insurance sector", not "medical sector", then yes, and that's a good thing. Eliminating this entire industry is perhaps the main feature of MFA. It's been done in many other countries, and those countries are happy with the result. The health insurance industry in Germany disappeared within 18 months of a public option. This is a good thing, because private health insurance can't compete with a government-run single-payer system. They are too expensive and have too much overhead (generally about 25% compared to about 5% for Medicare).

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: And millions more, who obtain their health insurance from their employer (more than 170 million people), would not want to keep working their marginal jobs if they could get their health insurance “free” from the government.

property.rebuttal: Not true. If companies no longer feel the need to pay for employees' health insurance, they will raise salaries accordingly. The total compensation would likely remain the same or similar. Also, I doubt this claim is true. Data from other countries would need to be provided to even start to support this claim.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: One of the most shocking pillars of the "Medicare for all" proposals being touted is the demolition of all private insurance. The resulting upheaval and displacement of health-care access across the board is the main reason that "Medicare for all" doesn’t have a chance of passing.

property.rebuttal: I don't know what specifically "upheaval and displacement of health-care access" means, but "access" seems to be a common phrase used in these discussions. It seems to mean "you have access to any medical procedure you want today, but wouldn't under MFA". Yes, you do have "access", if you mean you can pay a doctor a huge amount of money to do pretty much anything for you, even if it's unneeded or even harmful. Under a more regulated system, you wouldn't get that "nose job" (or whatever) "for free". But you could still pay your own money for it! So you wouldn't have any "less access" than today.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: to paste up a prefabricated government one-size-fits-all product.

property.rebuttal:
Keep in mind that he must be applying this labelling to current Medicare also. Yes, Medicare covers only a particular set of conditions. That's not bad. People on Medicare generally like it.
This is like saying that public libraries "paste up a prefabricate government one-size-fits-all product" by only providing a fixed set of books, newspapers, magazines, etc. Why is that bad? If you want other media, you can still go out and buy them!
The "paste up" term seems to imply that MFA would just be haphazardly thrown together without much thought. That's quite unlikely. In fact, a lot of though has already gone into the proposals, and they're just proposals at this point.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: Socialized health care across the board is not a good fit for America’s way of life.

property.rebuttal:
Why is that? Is there something unique about Americans' biology that requires them to pay more for health insurance? There is nothing inherently different about Americans, and even the culture in the US is not all that different from, say, Canada.
There's nothing about our "way of life" that says we like to pay about twice as much as the rest of the world for a below-average product. Even those few who have a "I'd rather die in pain than get government help" all gladly accept it when Medicare or Medicaid covers their hospital bills.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: You may not be able to keep your doctor under ObamaCare

property.rebuttal: An old, fully debunked argument. Obamacare did nothing to make people have to keep their doctors. Of course, it did nothing to stop doctors from dying, retiring, etc. The same goes for health insurance plans: if you liked your plan, you can keep it (with the obvious exception that the insurance company my stop offering it).

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome

property.quote: Of course, if "Medicare for all" ever passes, the senators and congressmen and congresswomen promoting it will quickly put together a plan to get their own high frills health coverage another way.

property.rebuttal: Perhaps. But today, members of congress get about the same benefits as anyone at any large company, and the federal government subsidizes most of their cost, again like at any large company.

object.name: Articles.Medicare for all is an expensive wrecking ball.WebHome
